Dear Arnold and Jim,

I would like to thankyou both for answering my question on Jingo tsuba. It
has been some time for me to reply because I am quite busy at work. I just
hope you did not think I was being rude by not replying earlier. Eitherway
sorry, and I will try and get a reply in sooner in future, since I really
appreciate the help. Now to the questions:

While staying on the topic of Higo Tsuba, I have some queries about the
Hayashi School that was patronized by the Kato, and later the Hosokawa clan.
I hope you can help. These tsuba seem to have a very 'gentlemanly'
appearence about them, which makes them to my mind very attractive pieces.

One tsuba I saw described was signed by the second mainline master
Shigemitsu. The commentary said that he must have been over 61 years in age
(since it was signed), as this had special significance in Japan, and in
Higo tsuba were only signed after this point in life.

A. What is the significance of turning 61 in Japan &

B. Why wait untill then to sign guards in Higo? Did other schools in Higo do
this as well, like the Jingo for example? How about entirely different
schools outside Higo, did they do this as well or not (doubtful?)

C. Last question(s), since I (again!) have never handled or even seen a
mainline Hayashi guard in the flesh or come up for sale, can anyone give me
an indication as to how this would compare value wise to say a mainline
Jingo Tsuba? Would this be similar since they are both Higo, or would it be
comparable to say a mainline Akasaka piece? (I am assuming that the pieces
are in excellent condition).

D. Very last question: If A and B are so important, and we know how
important it is to have signed works for reference, how does this translate
value wise to say perhaps two identical pieces. One signed and one mumei
with all other things being equal. What difference are we talking value wise
here, if any?

E. I promise this is my last question: If tsuba are signed only later in
life (in Higo) might this imply that they are better pieces since the maker
was more skilled at that time. Would a later identical tsuba be worth more
than an earlier one by the same man (supposing both were signed and dated
for arguments sake)?
In modern art a discussion has been raging for years about De Koonings work,
since it was found out that he had gone quiete senile later in life. This
led to a revaluation of his works, the earlier ones being worth more, since
no-one wanted a very expensive painting by someone who was for all intensive
purposes as Mad as a Hatter. Karel Apples early works are worth more than
his later ones as well, albeit for entirely different reasons.

Regards, Matthew

> Hi:
>  I will take a stab at your very interesting question, one of many that
> you seem to come up with. You have provided part of the answer yourself
> by saying "rare" though of course that begs the question, why rare?
> Jingo tsuba were made in Higo and the work of the first three
> generations is considered particularly fine, thereafter as in most lines
> following generations could not stop adding gold and silver effects,
> becoming too symmetric, adopting features from other groups, etc.
>  Higo, being remote from Edo, tended to supply products in the kodogu
> area, as with swords, that were somewhat outside the mainstream and they
> tended to be somewhat aloof from fashion elsewhere and to maintain that
> difference longer than other groups. Their market was more the samurai
> and less the merchant than would be true for people supplying the market
> in Edo and Osaka. The first three developed naturalistic designs never
> seen before or since, and thereby reflected the wabi sabi aesthetic that
> was very influential, particularly with the more severe samurai in the
> early Edo period. Their designs are very three dimensional, tastefully
> accented with gold and silver. Their most complementary counterpart
> seems to be found in the work of the Kanayama which, while sukashi, have
> the same rustic, subtle and unpretentious character. People also wonder
> whey they tend to go for some serious money. Jingo tsuba are instantly
> recognizable and fit well with any severe koshirae.
>  Just a stab.
>  Arnold
>
